description: black and white image of a fur hand muff with band aorund center with scroll design
signed: URC in the print: WHoller fecit. 1647
text:
Wenceslaus Hollar was a Bohemian prolific printmaker who had an international career, including work for the highest echelons of British aristocracy. In the 1640s, he joined other Royalists who fled the English Civil War, temporarily settling in Antwerp. There he worked on a series of etched still-lifes of muffs.

One immediately senses this pleasure this little accessory could bring. One of Hollar’s fashion plates shows a woman dressed for winter weather. She wears a muff, and beneath the image is a short verse:

The cold, not cruelty makes her wear
In Winter, furs and Wild beasts hair
For a smoother skin at night,
Embrace her with more delight.

In short, this fur also makes its wearer all the more desirable.
title: The Muff
